title: Holi
hero_image_alt: People celebrating Holi with colorful powders
short_description: The vibrant Festival of Colors, celebrating the arrival of spring and the triumph of good over evil with playful color throwing.
long_description:
Holi is perhaps India's most recognizable festival worldwide, a chaotic, joyous explosion of color that marks the arrival of spring. Ancient hindu mythology tells the story of Prahlad and Holika, symbolizing the burning of evil, which is enacted in the bonfire ritual of Holika Dahan on the eve of Holi. The next day, known as Rangwali Holi, is a free-for-all carnival of colors where social barriers dissolve. People of all ages, castes, and backgrounds chase each other with dry powder (gulal) and colored water, dance to drumbeats, and share festive sweets.

Beyond the playfulness, Holi holds deep cultural significance as a day of forgiveness and renewal. It is a time when old grudges are forgotten, and relationships are mended with an embrace and a smear of red brightness. Regionally, the celebrations vary wildly—from the stick-beating Lathmar Holi in Barsana to the royal processions of Rajasthan and the musical gatherings in Bengal. For the traveler, Holi is an immersive experience that is intensely physical, visually stunning, and emotionally uplifting.
significance: Holi celebrates the victory of Vishnu's devotee Prahlad over the demoness Holika, signified by the lighting of bonfires (Holika Dahan). It also honors the divine love of Radha and Krishna, who famously played with colors in Vrindavan.
key_rituals: Holika Dahan: Bonfires lit on the eve to burn evil spirits.
Rangwali Holi: Playing with gulal (colored powder) and water.
Drinking Thandai: A traditional spiced milk drink, sometimes infused with bhang (cannabis) in North India.
Singing & Dancing: Folk songs and drums (dhol) are central to the festivities.

calendar.lunar_reference: Full moon (Purnima) of the Phalguna month

top_places.title: Mathura & Vrindavan
top_places.summary: The birthplace of Lord Krishna, where Holi is celebrated for over a week with immense fervor.
top_places.best_to_experience: Traditional temple rituals and the famous Phoolon ki Holi (Flowers Holi).
top_places.how_to_reach: Nearest airport involves Delhi/Agra. Well connected by rail.

top_places.title: Barsana (Lathmar Holi)
top_places.summary: Unique tradition where women playfully beat men with sticks.
top_places.best_to_experience: Witnessing the energetic Lathmar Holi 4-5 days before the main event.

top_places.title: Shantiniketan (Basanta Utsav)
top_places.summary: A cultural celebration started by Rabindranath Tagore.
top_places.best_to_experience: Graceful dances, yellow clothes, and cultural performances rather than rowdy color play.

top_places.title: Udaipur
top_places.summary: Royal Holi celebrated by the Mewar royal family.
top_places.best_to_experience: The grand palace procession and Holika Dahan with the royal family.

top_places.title: Anandpur Sahib (Hola Mohalla)
top_places.summary: A Sikh festival celebrating martial arts just after Holi.
top_places.best_to_experience: Mock battles, sword fighting displays, and poetry.

practical_info.dress_tips: Wear old, white clothes that you don't mind getting stained forever. Sunglasses protect eyes.
practical_info.safety_tips: Use organic colors to avoid skin allergies. Protect hair with oil. Be cautious in large crowds.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Crowded streets can be difficult for wheelchairs.

faqs.q: Is Holi safe for solo female travelers?
faqs.a: It can be intense. We recommend joining organized group celebrations or staying within hotel events for a safer experience, especially in North India.
High-quality organic colors wash off easily. Cheap industrial dyes can stain skin for days. Moisturize heavily before playing.
